Soletta.when_to_pick: Gen 1 only with titanium to pay. Commits you to rush strategy. Otherwise skip.

Sponsored Mohole.name: Sponsored Mohole
Sponsored Mohole.economy: 8 MC total (5+3) for 2 heat prod (~8-12 MC). Req: Kelvinists ruling or 2 delegates. Building tag. Steel payable. 4 MC per heat prod is best rate in the game.
Sponsored Mohole.reasoning: Cheapest heat production in the game at 4 MC per prod. But Kelvinists requirement is restrictive. Krazyguy75 argues pushing Kelvinists lets opponents benefit from the ruling policy too. Building tag and steel payability help. benbever notes the 2 MC kickback when Kelvinists come to power. Good when Kelvinists align with your strategy naturally, bad when forced.
Sponsored Mohole.when_to_pick: When Kelvinists are already in power or you want them in power anyway. Do not force Kelvinists just for this.

Venus Allies.name: Venus Allies
Venus Allies.economy: 30+3=33 MC (ti-payable) for 2 Venus TR (18 MC) + 4 MC per colony + 2 VP (10 MC) + Venus+Space tags (~3-4 MC). At 2 colonies: 33-8=25 MC for 4 VP, decent. At 3: 33-12=21 MC for 4 VP, good.
Venus Allies.reasoning: No key commenter COTD data. With 2+ colonies it's a reasonable VP card. Ti-payable with Space tag helps. The 2 Venus TR raises the track which can help Venus requirements. At 3 colonies, 21 MC for 4 VP + 2 Venus TR is solid. Late game VP card that works with colony + Venus combo strategy.
Venus Allies.when_to_pick: Late game with 2+ colonies and ti to pay. Better in Venus-heavy games. Skip without colonies.

Corroder Suits.name: Corroder Suits
Corroder Suits.economy: 8+3=11 MC for 2 MC-prod (10 MC) + Venus tag (2-3 MC) + 1 Venus resource (~1-5 MC depending on target). Total ~13-18 MC.
Corroder Suits.reasoning: Essentially Sponsors +2 MC cost with a Venus tag instead of Earth tag and a bonus Venus resource. The Venus tag is less valuable than Earth tag in most games (fewer Venus synergies). The Venus resource varies from worthless (no target) to strong (1 VP animal). Early play for MC-prod is decent, late play for VP resource is decent, but the card is conflicted -- early play means no good resource target, late play means MC-prod is less valuable.
Corroder Suits.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 for MC-prod if Venus tag helps with award/milestone. Late game if you have a 1-VP Venus animal.

Pets.name: Pets
Pets.economy: Cost 10+3=13 MC. Value: 1 VP per 2 animals. With 6-8 cities total = 3-4 VP (15-20 MC). Earth+Animal tags (3-5). Total ~18-25 MC over full game. Pure VP card.
Pets.reasoning: Pure VP card that needs early play for maximum value but conflicts with early-game economy needs. In 3P all-expansions, cities are moderate (5-8 total). shai_aus rates it medium -- good in city-heavy games, mediocre otherwise. The 1VP/2 animals ratio is worse than 1VP/1 animal cards. Earth+Animal tags have synergy value. Meat Industry combo is strong.
Pets.when_to_pick: When you expect 6+ cities and can play gen 1-2. With Meat Industry it becomes much better. Otherwise low priority.

Aqueduct Systems.name: Aqueduct Systems
Aqueduct Systems.economy: 9+3=12 MC (in steel) for 3 Building cards (9-12 MC) + 1 VP (5 MC) + Building tag (1-2 MC). Total ~15-19 MC. Good if requirement met.
Aqueduct Systems.reasoning: 3 Building card draw + 1 VP + Building tag for 12 MC in steel is good value, but the requirement (city adjacent to ocean) is awkward. You typically do not want cities near oceans, and building a city just for this is expensive. If the requirement happens to be met, the card is good. Building cards are hit-or-miss in quality. Niche but acceptable when stars align.
Aqueduct Systems.when_to_pick: Only when you already have a city next to an ocean and have steel to spend. Do not build around this card.

Bio Printing Facility.name: Bio Printing Facility
Bio Printing Facility.economy: 7+3=10 MC for Building tag (1-2 MC) + action: 2 energy -> 2 plants or 1 animal. With 1VP animal: ~5 MC/action. With plants: ~2 MC/action (plants vs heat).
Bio Printing Facility.reasoning: Cheap card with a flexible action, but requires energy production to function. The animal placement mode is strong with 1-VP-per-animal cards (Birds, Fish, Livestock) -- effectively converting 2 energy to 1 VP. The plant mode is mediocre since energy already converts to heat. Best as an animal feeder when you have excess energy from Mass Converter/Quantum Extractor. Without energy, useless.
Bio Printing Facility.when_to_pick: When you have 2+ excess energy-prod AND a 1-VP animal card. Otherwise low priority.

Deep Well Heating.name: Deep Well Heating
Deep Well Heating.economy: 13 MC (steel payable) + 3 MC card = 16 MC cost. Returns: 1 TR (~7.2 MC) + 1 energy-prod (~7.5 MC) + Power+Building tags (~3 MC). Total ~17.7 MC value. Tiny bundle discount.
Deep Well Heating.reasoning: Mediocre card that does two things you rarely need together. Per icehawk84, it's fair value but rarely what you want — if you need energy you pay for temperature you don't need, and vice versa. Per FieldMouse007, best use is holding it for later as a steel dump when you need a surprise heat/energy boost. The 2 tags (Power+Building) are its best feature.
Deep Well Heating.when_to_pick: When you have steel to dump and need both energy production and temperature advancement. Good early with steel resources.

Floating Habs.name: Floating Habs
Floating Habs.economy: 5 MC + 3 MC card = 8 MC cost. Action: spend 2 MC to add floater here OR add floater to any card. 1 VP per 2 floaters. 2 Science tag req. Venus tag.
Floating Habs.reasoning: Best VP-per-floater ratio (1 per 2), but on its own 2 MC per floater means 4 MC per VP which isn't great with an 8 MC investment. Per benbever, best use is as a floater distributor to other cards where floaters are worth more. The 2 Science tag requirement limits accessibility. Good with Titan colony for bulk floater dumps. Per community, not a high priority on its own but good in floater engines.
Floating Habs.when_to_pick: Mid game with Titan colony or 2+ floater dispensers. Good floater dump target for Hoverlord.

Fueled Generators.name: Fueled Generators
Fueled Generators.economy: 1 MC + 3 MC card = 4 MC cost. Net effect: -1 MC-prod (~-5 MC gen1) + 1 energy-prod (~7.5 MC gen1). Net gain: ~2.5 MC value gen1. Power+Building tags (~3 MC).
Fueled Generators.reasoning: Cheapest energy production in the game with useful dual tags. Per shai_aus, going on upfront cost it's the cheapest energy and cheapest building — if either matters, it's decent. Per ad_hocNC, it's a bad deal but energy 'now' has value. The -1 MC production hurts long-term but if you need immediate energy for cities, trading, or card effects, the 4 MC upfront cost is hard to beat. Better than SP Power Plant at 11 MC.
Fueled Generators.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 when you urgently need energy production for another card and have no better energy source.

Gyropolis.name: Gyropolis
Gyropolis.economy: 20 MC + 14 MC (2 energy prod) + 3 MC card = ~37 MC total. Need 5+ Earth/Venus tags for 5+ MC-prod to break even. City worth ~2 VP. At 5 tags: 25 MC prod value + 10 MC city = 35 MC, barely even.
Gyropolis.reasoning: Very expensive city that requires significant Earth/Venus tag investment to justify. In 3P with all expansions, games are ~8 gen so production payoff window is narrow. Better in 2P with more gens. Steel payable is nice but energy cost hurts with Colonies trading.
Gyropolis.when_to_pick: Mid-late game steel dump when you have 5+ Earth/Venus tags and excess energy production. Good for Banker award snipe.

Imported GHG.name: Imported GHG
Imported GHG.economy: 7 MC + 3 MC card = 10 MC for 1 heat prod (~4-6 MC) + 3 heat (~3.75 MC) = ~8-10 MC value. Earth+Space event tags. Barely breaks even without discounts.
Imported GHG.reasoning: Marginal value on its own but excellent with discount infrastructure. The Earth+Space event triple-tag combo enables massive discounts. With Optimal Aerobraking alone it becomes profitable. The 3 instant heat can be clutch for sniping a temperature bonus. Low impact overall but very cheap and flexible.
Imported GHG.when_to_pick: When you have 2+ discount/rebate cards active. With Optimal Aerobraking, almost always play. Without discounts, it's marginal.

Mineral Deposit.name: Mineral Deposit
Mineral Deposit.economy: Cost 5+3=8 MC. Value: 5 steel (10 MC). Net +2 MC. No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Event for Legend. Better with rebates.
Mineral Deposit.reasoning: Small but positive value if you can spend the steel. The no-tag penalty hurts significantly. With IC/Media Group rebates it becomes good. benbever notes it's good for Legend milestone and Miner award. Low impact but rarely bad. Not worth a high draft pick.
Mineral Deposit.when_to_pick: When you have event rebates or need steel for specific plays. Low draft priority. Good as free draw.

New Holland.name: New Holland
New Holland.economy: Cost 20+3=23 MC (steel payable). Value: 3 MC-prod (15-18) + City (placement VP) + City+Building tags (2-3). Req: 4 cities on Mars. Net ~-5 to -2.
New Holland.reasoning: Interesting concept but 4 cities on Mars requirement is very difficult to meet in 3P before good spots are gone. No COTD data available. The 3 MC-prod is decent and it's steel payable. Placing a city on an ocean tile is unique but the requirement severely limits playability. Niche promo card.
New Holland.when_to_pick: Only when 4+ cities exist on Mars AND good ocean spots remain for city placement. Very rare scenario.

Nitrogen from Titan.name: Nitrogen from Titan
Nitrogen from Titan.economy: Cost 25+3=28 MC (ti payable). Value: 2 TR (14.8) + 1 VP (5) + 2 floaters (~3) + Jovian+Space tags (4-7). Total ~27-30 MC. Break-even with tags.
Nitrogen from Titan.reasoning: A typical 'yet another Jovian' card. In isolation it's mediocre, but with multipliers and ti-discounts it becomes decent. The floaters on a Jovian card can add value (Jovian Lanterns for +1 VP). Krazyguy75 says at best it's good, never bad. Requires synergy to shine. Ti-payable helps in late game.
Nitrogen from Titan.when_to_pick: Late game with Jovian multipliers and titanium to spend. Low priority without specific synergy.

PR Office.name: PR Office
PR Office.economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: 1 TR (7-7.4) + 1 MC per Earth tag + Earth tag (2-3). Req: Unity ruling/2 delegates. At 3 Earth tags = 3 MC refund. Net ~0-3 MC.
PR Office.reasoning: Fairly priced TR with Earth tag refund. At 1 Earth tag (this one), it's 10 MC for 1 TR + 1 MC which is mediocre. With 4+ Earth tags it becomes good value. The Unity party requirement is manageable but limits flexibility. COTD has no key commenter data. A filler Turmoil card.
PR Office.when_to_pick: With 3+ Earth tags when Unity is ruling. Otherwise skip.

Recruitment.name: Recruitment
Recruitment.economy: 5 MC total (2+3) for replacing a neutral delegate with yours. Same cost as placing a delegate but more powerful (removes neutral). No tags = -3 to -5 penalty.
Recruitment.reasoning: Cheap political card that is strictly better than placing a delegate in certain situations. Can steal party leadership surprise. No tags hurts. Event tag useless. Very situational - depends on Turmoil board state. In 3P it can be powerful for stealing Chairman.
Recruitment.when_to_pick: When Turmoil is in play and you need to contest party leadership. Hold for optimal timing.

Satellites.name: Satellites
Satellites.economy: 13 MC total (10+3) for X MC-prod (1 per space tag including this). Space tag. Event space tags don't count. Need 3+ space tags for decent value.
Satellites.reasoning: Needs many non-event space tags to be worthwhile, which is difficult. shai_aus notes event space tags do not count, making it much weaker. Best for Banker award sniping. With 4+ space tags it gives 4+ MC-prod for 13 MC which is decent. Very niche and strategy-dependent.
Satellites.when_to_pick: When you have 3+ non-event space tags played. Can swing Banker award. Otherwise skip.

Trans-Neptune Probe.name: Trans-Neptune Probe
Trans-Neptune Probe.economy: 6+3=9 MC (ti-payable) for 1 VP (5 MC) + Science+Space tags (~5-7 MC). With ti: ~3-5 MC effective cost. Enables science requirements.
Trans-Neptune Probe.reasoning: Boring but functional. icehawk84 notes it's 'a cheap tag to unlock science payoffs.' FieldMouse007 calls it 'overpriced 1pt unless you have too much titanium.' The dual Science+Space tag is genuinely useful for requirements, making this mostly a tag enabler with a small VP bonus. Best when ti is available.
Trans-Neptune Probe.when_to_pick: When you need a science tag for requirements and have titanium to spend. Late game VP dump. Not a priority pick.

Tropical Resort.name: Tropical Resort
Tropical Resort.economy: 13+3=16 MC (steel-payable) for -2 heat-prod + 3 MC-prod + 2 VP. If heat-prod has no remaining value: 16 MC for 3 MC-prod (barely used) + 2 VP (10 MC). Building tag ~1-2 MC.
Tropical Resort.reasoning: Primarily a late-game VP card when temperature is maxed and heat production is worthless. benbever confirms 'definitely a late game card - use when you can't use your heat anymore.' 16 MC for 2 VP is below average but steel-payable helps. The 3 MC-prod helps with Banker. Not worth early play.
Tropical Resort.when_to_pick: Last gen or second to last when temperature is maxed and you have heat-prod to sacrifice. Steel-payable makes it cheaper.

Water Import From Europa.name: Water Import From Europa
Water Import From Europa.economy: 25+3=28 MC (ti-payable) for action: pay 12 MC (ti OK) for 1 ocean + 1 VP per Jovian tag. Jovian multiplier: at 4 tags = 4 VP (20 MC) + ocean action. Ocean at 12 MC vs SP 18 MC = 6 MC savings/use.
Water Import From Europa.reasoning: One of 4 Jovian multipliers. benbever's detailed analysis shows the ocean action is decent (6 MC under SP, ti-payable) but the real value is VP scaling. shai_aus calls it 'probably the worst Jovian multiplier' but FieldMouse007 notes 5+ VP makes it decent. Hate-draft priority against Jovian players. Flexible timing: can play early for oceans or late for VP.
Water Import From Europa.when_to_pick: In Jovian strategy for the multiplier VP. Hate-draft against Jovian players. Ocean action is bonus. Ti-payable is key.

Martian Lumber Corp.name: Martian Lumber Corp
Martian Lumber Corp.reasoning: Plant тег для NRA. Ongoing effect слабый.

Airliners.name: Airliners
Airliners.reasoning: Req сложный. No tags penalty. Floater bonus.

ArchaeBacteria.name: ArchaeBacteria
ArchaeBacteria.economy: 6+3=9 MC for 1 plant-prod (8 MC gen 1). Microbe tag worth 1-2 MC. Max -18C easy to meet gen 1. 9 MC total, ~9-10 MC value. Fair.
ArchaeBacteria.reasoning: Cheapest plant production in the game at 9 MC total, but gives a Microbe tag instead of the more valuable Plant tag. The max -18C requirement is almost always met gen 1. Fair value as a gen 1 play to start greenery accumulation, but 1 plant-prod alone does little -- you need additional plant sources. The Microbe tag has niche synergy with Decomposers, Advanced Ecosystems.
synergies: Nitrogen Rich Asteroid (needs plant tag instead)
ArchaeBacteria.when_to_pick: Gen 1 only, when you need cheap plant production and have no better options. The Microbe tag is less useful than Plant tag.

Artificial Photosynthesis.name: Artificial Photosynthesis
Artificial Photosynthesis.economy: 12+3=15 MC for Science tag (3-5 MC) + 2 energy-prod (15 MC) or 1 plant-prod (8 MC). Energy mode: 7.5 MC/prod, slightly above average.
Artificial Photosynthesis.reasoning: Overpriced for production alone, but the Science tag adds value. 2 energy-prod for 15 MC (7.5 MC each) is acceptable but not good -- Geothermal Power and Solar Wind Power are better deals. The plant-prod option is terrible (15 MC for 1 plant-prod). Mainly played for the Science tag when you need energy production and a science requirement. Functional but uninspiring.
Artificial Photosynthesis.when_to_pick: When you need a Science tag AND 2 energy-prod. Otherwise find cheaper energy or better Science tags.

Giant Space Mirror.name: Giant Space Mirror
Giant Space Mirror.economy: 17 MC + 3 MC card = 20 MC cost. Returns: 3 energy-prod (~22.5 MC gen1) + Space tag (~2 MC). Total ~24.5 MC. Efficiency: 6.7 MC per energy-prod.
Giant Space Mirror.reasoning: Overpriced energy production. 20 MC for 3 energy-prod is better per-unit than SP Power Plant but the bulk cost is painful. Per benbever in other COTD threads, it's rarely worth playing unless you can pay significant portion in titanium. The Space tag enables ti payment which is the main draw. There are usually better energy sources available. Colonies make energy more valuable but 20 MC gen1 is a lot.
Giant Space Mirror.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 with titanium to pay and immediate need for 3 energy (Colonies, multiple energy-dependent cards).

Grass.name: Grass
Grass.economy: 11 MC + 3 MC card = 14 MC cost. Returns: 1 plant-prod (~8 MC gen1) + 3 plants (~6 MC) + Plant tag (~2 MC). Total ~16 MC. Requires -16°C.
Grass.reasoning: Basic plant card with easy requirement. The 3 immediate plants plus 1 plant-prod is modest but playable early when plants help toward greeneries. Per community, plant production cards are generally mediocre in all-expansion games because games are shorter. At 14 MC it's slightly below break-even for gen 1 play. The Plant tag helps NRA and Ecologist. Similar to but worse than Bushes (same cost, 2 plant-prod instead of 1 + 4 plants).
Grass.when_to_pick: Gen 1-3 with plant synergy and a path to early greeneries. Not worth keeping for late game.

SF Memorial.name: SF Memorial
SF Memorial.economy: 10 MC total (7+3) for 1 card (~4 MC) + 1 VP (~5 MC) + Building tag (~1 MC). Total value ~10 MC. Break-even. Steel payable.
SF Memorial.reasoning: Simple, boring card. 10 MC for 1 card + 1 VP is fair but uninspiring. Building tag helps for milestones. Best as a steel dump. shai_aus says 'maybe if desperate.' icehawk84 confirms 'not hugely impactful.' Free draw makes it more playable since you save the 3 MC draft cost.
SF Memorial.when_to_pick: Late game steel dump for 1 VP. Not worth drafting early unless desperate for building tags.

Wave Power.name: Wave Power
Wave Power.economy: 8+3=11 MC for 1 energy-prod (7.5 MC) + 1 VP (5 MC) + Power tag (~1 MC). Req 3 oceans. Total ~13.5 MC. Slight value gain. Steel-payable helps.
Wave Power.reasoning: Cheap energy production with a VP bonus. 11 MC for 1 energy-prod + 1 VP is acceptable efficiency. The 3 ocean requirement is usually met by gen 3-4. Power tag is niche. In Colonies, energy for trading adds value. A decent filler card that's never exciting but rarely terrible.
Wave Power.when_to_pick: When you need energy production and 3 oceans are down. Fine filler. Better with Colonies.

Supermarkets.name: Supermarkets
Supermarkets.reasoning: MC-prod + VP но no tags penalty. Строго хуже Acquired Company.

Ants.name: Ants
Ants.economy: 9+3=12 MC for Microbe tag + action: 1/2 VP per microbe. Self-generating: ~3-4 VP over 6-7 gens (play gen 2-3). Anti-microbe attack is bonus.
Ants.reasoning: Decent VP generator with 1/2 VP per microbe, but slow (1 microbe per gen via action). 4% oxygen requirement is mild. The anti-microbe ability is situational -- sometimes strong (stealing from Decomposers, Tardigrades) but often no good targets. Best with Extreme-Cold Fungus, Enceladus colony, Bactoviral Research. Without these, ~3 VP for 12 MC is merely acceptable.
Ants.when_to_pick: When you have microbe synergy (Enceladus, Extreme-Cold Fungus) or opponents have vulnerable microbe cards. Mid-priority.

Cloud Tourism.name: Cloud Tourism
Cloud Tourism.economy: 11+3=14 MC for Venus tag (2-3 MC) + MC-prod per Earth/Venus pair. With 2 pairs: 2 MC-prod (10 MC). 1/3 VP per floater is slow. Action adds floaters.
Cloud Tourism.reasoning: Requires both Earth AND Venus tag investment to generate meaningful MC-prod, which is a narrow niche. The 1/3 VP per floater is very slow. With 2 Earth+Venus pairs, 2 MC-prod for 14 MC is fair but requires substantial tag investment. The floater generation helps with Hoverlord milestone. Mostly for dedicated Venus+Earth crossover strategies which are uncommon. Niche but functional.
Cloud Tourism.when_to_pick: When you have 2+ Earth tags AND 2+ Venus tags. Very niche. Skip without dual-tag investment.

Community Services.name: Community Services
Community Services.economy: 13+3=16 MC for 1 VP (5 MC) + N MC-prod where N = no-tag cards (including this). Average 2-3 no-tag cards: 2-3 MC-prod (10-15 MC). No tags = -3 to -5.
Community Services.reasoning: The no-tag penalty is somewhat mitigated since the card actively rewards having no-tag cards. With 3 no-tag cards (including itself) you get 3 MC-prod + 1 VP for 16 MC, which is acceptable. But building around no-tag cards is generally a losing strategy since tags are valuable. Best as a side benefit when you happen to have several no-tag cards (Caretaker Contract, Indentured Workers, etc.). The Sagitta corp synergy is notable.
Community Services.when_to_pick: When you have 3+ no-tag cards already. Not worth building around.

Geothermal Power.name: Geothermal Power
Geothermal Power.economy: 11 MC + 3 MC card = 14 MC cost. Returns: 2 energy-prod (~15 MC gen1) + Power+Building tags (~3 MC). Total ~18 MC. Efficiency: 7 MC per energy-prod.
Geothermal Power.reasoning: Straightforward energy production card at fair but unexciting value. 14 MC for 2 energy production is ~7 MC per energy-prod, which is the same as SP Power Plant (11 MC for 1) after accounting for the card cost. The Power+Building tags provide some tag synergy. Per community, it's playable but rarely exciting — you'd rather find energy from cheaper sources or cards that do more than just give energy.
Geothermal Power.when_to_pick: Gen 1-3 when you need energy production and nothing better is available. Steel payable helps.

Luxury Foods.name: Luxury Foods
Luxury Foods.economy: 8 MC + 3 MC card = 11 MC for 2 VP (~10 MC). Requires Venus+Earth+Jovian tags. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. 5.5 MC/VP.
Luxury Foods.reasoning: Mediocre VP card with no tags. At 5.5 MC per VP it's slightly above the 5 MC/VP threshold but the triple tag requirement and no tags on the card itself make it unexciting. Good last-gen point dump if requirements are met. The requirements are usually met naturally with all expansions. No ongoing value, pure VP. Not worth going out of your way for.
Luxury Foods.when_to_pick: Last gen point dump when you meet the requirements and have nothing better. Don't draft unless requirements are easy.

Phobos Space Haven.name: Phobos Space Haven
Phobos Space Haven.economy: Cost 25+3=28 MC (ti payable). Value: 3 VP (15) + 1 ti-prod (12.5) + Space+City tags (2-3) + city (no Mars bonuses). Total ~30-31 MC. Net ~+2-3 MC but ti-prod is often wasted late.
Phobos Space Haven.reasoning: 3 VP for 28 MC (ti payable) is okay as late-game titanium dump, but the 1 titanium production is wasted if played late. The city isn't on Mars so it doesn't count for most awards/milestones. shai_aus rates it too expensive and bad value. icehawk84 prefers Interstellar Colony Ship. Only play as an endgame titanium dump.
Phobos Space Haven.when_to_pick: Last 1-2 gens as titanium dump for 3 VP. Don't play for production -- too slow.

Physics Complex.name: Physics Complex
Physics Complex.economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC (steel payable). Action: 6 energy -> 2 VP. At 3 uses = 6 VP for 15 + ~18 energy cost = 33 MC total. 5.5 MC/VP. Science+Building tags (4-7).
Physics Complex.reasoning: The 'newbie trap' card that looks amazing but is usually mediocre. 6 energy per action is an enormous cost that could be used for temperature/trading. icehawk84 notes it's a scaling late-game card but warns against early play. SoupsBane calculates 4 uses minimum for playability. The Science+Building tags are the best part. Only good with Mass Converter-level energy surplus.
Physics Complex.when_to_pick: Only with 6+ energy production and no better use for it. The tags alone can justify it as a steel dump.

Robot Pollinators.name: Robot Pollinators
Robot Pollinators.economy: 12 MC total (9+3) for 1 plant prod (~8 MC) + X plants (1 per plant tag). No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. Req 4% oxygen. Worse Insects without plant tag.
Robot Pollinators.reasoning: Mediocre plant production card without a plant tag, which is a significant downside (no NRA/Insects synergy). The plant-per-tag bonus is variable and often small. benbever confirms it has no plant tag despite appearances. No tag penalty hurts. Comparable to Grass but strictly worse than Insects.
Robot Pollinators.when_to_pick: Only when you have many plant tags and need the extra plants for a greenery. Low priority.

Special Permit.name: Special Permit
Special Permit.economy: 8 MC total (5+3) for steal 4 plants from opponent + Plant event tag. Req: Greens ruling or 2 delegates. Take-that in 3P. 4 stolen plants = 0.5 greenery swing.
Special Permit.reasoning: Take-that card in 3P format deserves penalty. Stealing 4 plants hurts one opponent but benefits the third for free. Greens requirement adds timing difficulty. Plant tag is nice for synergies. Not as bad as pure take-that cards since you gain the plants yourself, making it a resource transfer rather than pure destruction. Very situational.
Special Permit.when_to_pick: Only when Greens are ruling and you can immediately use the stolen plants. Niche.

Supercapacitors.name: Supercapacitors
Supercapacitors.economy: 4+3=7 MC for 1 MC-prod (5-6 MC) + energy storage ability + Power+Building tags. Tags for Aridor/Diversifier worth ~2-4 MC. Energy storage helps with Colony trading.
Supercapacitors.reasoning: Cheap card with useful dual tags. The 1 MC-prod alone almost justifies the cost. Energy storage is niche but helpful for Colonies trading when you have 2 energy-prod. benbever details good use cases. Mostly a tag card with a small production bonus. Fine but low impact.
Supercapacitors.when_to_pick: When tags matter (Diversifier, Builder milestones) or with Colonies and limited energy. Cheap enough to play most times.

Water to Venus.name: Water to Venus
Water to Venus.economy: 9+3=12 MC (ti-payable) for 1 Venus TR (9 MC). Space event tag. With discounts (IC -2, space discounts -2 to -4): can be 2-6 MC for 1 TR. With Optimal Aerobraking: +3 heat bonus.
Water to Venus.reasoning: icehawk84 says 'efficient with all possible discounts and rebates but never exciting.' benbever details how with discounts/ti this can be near-free TR. FieldMouse007 calls it 'ok card, cheaper standard project.' The Space event tag makes it flexible for Legend, IC, Media Group. Not bad, just unexciting - a discount-dependent card.
Water to Venus.when_to_pick: When you have space/event discounts and need Venus TR. Ti-payable makes it accessible. Late-game ti dump.

Windmills.name: Windmills
Windmills.economy: 6+3=9 MC (steel-payable) for 1 energy-prod (7.5 MC) + 1 VP (5 MC) + Power+Building tags (~2-3 MC). Req 7% O2. Total ~15 MC. Very cheap with steel.
Windmills.reasoning: shai_aus says 'it's fine. Pretty cheap, gives you a point, lets you use excess steel.' Power+Building dual tags are useful for Builder milestone and energy needs. 7% O2 requirement (step 10/14) limits to mid-late game. With steel payment it's very cheap for 1 VP + energy. Modest but efficient.
Windmills.when_to_pick: When 7% O2 is met and you have steel. Cheap VP + energy. Fine filler for late game.

Biomass Combustors.name: Biomass Combustors
Biomass Combustors.reasoning: -1 plant-prod opponent. Take-that penalty. Building+Microbe теги спасают.

House Printing.name: House Printing
House Printing.reasoning: 1 steel-prod + 1 VP. Building тег. Marginal value.

Air-Scrapping Expedition.name: Air-Scrapping Expedition
Air-Scrapping Expedition.economy: 13+3=16 MC for 1 Venus TR (7 MC) + 3 floaters (~3-4.5 MC). Net ~10.5 MC, overpays by ~5.5 MC. Ti-payable. Event tag has synergy value.
Air-Scrapping Expedition.reasoning: Slightly cheaper than the Venus standard project (15 MC), with 3 bonus floaters and a Venus tag. The floaters add value if you have Stratopolis, Floating Habs, or Hoverlord milestone. Without floater targets, it is mediocre -- paying 16 MC for 1 TR is poor. The Venus event tag enables Media Group, Optimal Aerobraking synergies. Situational but acceptable with the right floater cards.
Air-Scrapping Expedition.when_to_pick: When you have Venus floater cards in play and need a Venus raise. Skip without floater synergy.

City Parks.name: City Parks
City Parks.economy: 7+3=10 MC for 2 VP (10 MC) + 2 plants (4 MC) + Building tag (1-2 MC). Total ~15 MC. Requires 3 cities. Building tag, steel-payable.
City Parks.reasoning: 2 VP + 2 plants for 10 MC is good value, but the 3 cities requirement is very hard to meet. Most players play 1-2 cities in a typical 3P game. You need to be specifically building cities for this to work, which is generally not an efficient strategy. If you happen to have 3 cities (rare), the card is cheap VP. Steel-payable is nice. Too conditional for most games.
City Parks.when_to_pick: Only when you have or expect 3 cities, which is rare in 3P. Do not build cities to enable this.

Comet Aiming.name: Comet Aiming
Comet Aiming.economy: 17+3=20 MC for Space tag. Action: 1 ti -> 1 asteroid (2 gens = 1 ocean). 1st ocean: 23 MC (including 1 ti). Better than Aquifer Pumping rate but still slow.
Comet Aiming.reasoning: Better than Aquifer Pumping but still expensive upfront (20 MC). Converting titanium to oceans every 2 gens is decent if you have ti-production. With Astrodrill or external asteroid sources, much better (1 ocean per gen). Without asteroid synergy, ~2-3 oceans over the game for ~25-30 MC total is acceptable but not exciting. Space tag is useful. Main value is with asteroid card combos.
Comet Aiming.when_to_pick: When you have ti-production and asteroid card synergy. Medium priority with Astrodrill. Lower without.

Comet for Venus.name: Comet for Venus
Comet for Venus.economy: 11+3=14 MC for 1 Venus TR (7 MC) + remove 4 MC from Venus-tagged player (~2-4 MC value in 3P). Space tag (1-2 MC). Ti-payable. Event synergies.
Comet for Venus.reasoning: 1 MC cheaper than Venus standard project, with a minor attack. In 3P the MC removal helps the third player (take-that penalty). Ti-payable via Space tag. Event tag enables synergies. Mostly played as a cheap Venus raise with ti payment and event rebates. Without discounts, barely better than the standard project. The attack is too minor and conditional to matter much.
Comet for Venus.when_to_pick: When you need a Venus raise and have ti/event discounts. Skip without discounts.

Directed Impactors.name: Directed Impactors
Directed Impactors.economy: 8 MC + 3 MC card = 11 MC cost. Action: 6 MC (ti payable) → 1 asteroid → spend for 1 temp raise. Effective: ~17 MC per TR (11 initial + 6 per use). With ti: cheaper.
Directed Impactors.reasoning: A mediocre terraforming engine. 6 MC + 2 actions per TR is slow and expensive compared to standard projects. Per FieldMouse007, needs to raise temperature at least 2-3 times to be playable. Per icehawk84, asteroid cards tend to eat titanium needed for better things. The Space tag and ti payability help somewhat. Only worth it if rushing temperature early with titanium to spare.
Directed Impactors.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 if rushing temperature with excess titanium. Skip if mid-game or later.

Greenhouses.name: Greenhouses
Greenhouses.economy: 6 MC (steel payable) + 3 MC card = 9 MC cost. Returns: X plants where X = cities in play. In 3P mid-game typically 2-4 cities = 2-4 plants (~4-8 MC). Plant+Building tags (~3 MC).
Greenhouses.reasoning: Cheap one-shot plant generator that scales with cities. In 3P with 3-4 cities, you get 3-4 plants for 9 MC which is barely break-even. The Plant+Building tags help NRA and Builder. Per community, it's a late-game play when more cities are down and plants are worth more for final greenery conversions. Very dependent on city count which varies widely. Steel payable is nice.
Greenhouses.when_to_pick: Late game with 5+ cities for a final plant burst toward greenery conversion. Low priority otherwise.

Hired Raiders.name: Hired Raiders
Hired Raiders.economy: 1 MC + 3 MC card = 4 MC cost. Steal 2 steel (~4 MC) or 3 MC. Nearly cost-neutral. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty.
Hired Raiders.reasoning: Almost breaks even on its own which is rare for attack cards. In 3P, stealing from one opponent helps the third player, but the near-zero net cost mitigates this. No tags is a significant penalty. Better in 2P. With IC/Media Group it becomes genuinely profitable. The steal can disrupt key steel plays.
Hired Raiders.when_to_pick: When you have event rebates or need to disrupt a specific opponent's steel plans. Don't draft early without synergies.

Hydrogen to Venus.name: Hydrogen to Venus
Hydrogen to Venus.economy: 11 MC + 3 MC card = 14 MC for 1 Venus TR (~7 MC). Floaters are conditional on Jovian tags AND Venus floater card. Space tag for titanium payment. Without floaters: 7 MC value for 14 MC = bad.
Hydrogen to Venus.reasoning: Overpriced Venus TR without the floater bonus. Requires both Jovian tags AND a Venus floater card to get good value, which is an unlikely combo. As a titanium dump for 1 Venus TR it's barely passable at 14 MC (vs 15 MC standard project). The Space tag and ti-payable save it from F-tier. Highly situational.
Hydrogen to Venus.when_to_pick: Only when you have Jovian tags AND a Venus floater card. Otherwise, pass.

Ironworks.name: Ironworks
Ironworks.economy: 11 MC + 3 MC card = 14 MC upfront. Action: 4 energy (~6 MC) for 1 O2 step (7 MC TR) + 1 steel (2 MC) = ~9 MC value. Net per use: +3 MC. Need 4+ uses to pay off the card.
Ironworks.reasoning: Niche oxygen bumper that requires significant energy investment. In 3P with all expansions, energy is often needed for colony trading, making the 4 energy per use expensive. Need 4+ bumps to break even, which requires ~5 gens of use. Better in 2P where there's less competition for oxygen track and more generations. The Building tag and steel output are minor bonuses.
Ironworks.when_to_pick: When you have 4+ energy production with no colony trading needs and want to compete on oxygen track. Mostly a 2P card.

Local Shading.name: Local Shading
Local Shading.economy: 4 MC + 3 MC card = 7 MC. Venus tag. Action: add 1 floater or spend 1 floater for +1 MC-prod. Effectively: 1 MC-prod per 2 actions, but can receive floaters from other sources.
Local Shading.reasoning: Cheap Venus tag with a slow MC production engine. Building MC-prod one at a time over 2 actions is extremely slow, but the card is so cheap that even 2-3 MC-prod over the game is acceptable. Better as a floater target for other cards. The Venus tag has synergy value. Cheap enough to play just for the tag without feeling bad.
Local Shading.when_to_pick: When you need a cheap Venus tag or a floater target. The MC-prod generation is a bonus, not the primary reason.

Magnetic Field Generators:promo.name: Magnetic Field Generators:promo
Magnetic Field Generators:promo.economy: Cost 22+3=25 MC (steel payable). Value: 2 plant-prod (16) + 3 TR (22.2) + tile = 38+. But -4 energy-prod is huge (-30). Net ~8 MC value. Building tag helps.
Magnetic Field Generators:promo.reasoning: The massive energy cost of -4 makes this extremely situational. You need heavy energy surplus to even consider it. The TR + plant-prod package is solid but the energy requirement locks it into late-game niche plays. Building tag and steel-payable help slightly.
Magnetic Field Generators:promo.when_to_pick: Only when you have 5+ energy production with no better use for it. Late-game steel dump with excess energy.

Market Manipulation.name: Market Manipulation
Market Manipulation.economy: Cost 1+3=4 MC. Value: +1 colony track step (~2-3 MC) + deny opponent ~2-3 MC. Net roughly break-even. Earth tag worth 2-3 MC. Event tag for Legend.
Market Manipulation.reasoning: Low impact but cheap. The Earth+Event tag combo enables rebates (Media Group +3, IC +2, Point Luna card). Without rebates it's marginally worth playing; with rebates it becomes decent. Krazyguy75 argues it's too low-impact; benbever says it's almost always good. In 3P it's solidly mediocre.
Market Manipulation.when_to_pick: When you have event/Earth tag rebates. Low draft priority otherwise. Good as a free draw.

Mining Expedition.name: Mining Expedition
Mining Expedition.economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC. Value: 1 O2 TR (7-7.4) + 2 steel (4 MC) - take-that penalty (5-10 in 3P). Net ~-4 to +1 MC. No tags = penalty.
Mining Expedition.reasoning: The 2 plant removal is take-that which hurts in 3P (helps the 3rd player for free). The no-tag penalty compounds the issue. The O2 raise is useful for snatching the 8% temperature bonus or enabling requirements. 2 steel is a small consolation. Niche applications exist but generally mediocre.
Mining Expedition.when_to_pick: To snatch O2 bonuses or end the game. Take-that in 3P is a real downside. Low priority in draft.

Ore Processor.name: Ore Processor
Ore Processor.economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC (steel payable). Action: spend 4 energy for 1 titanium (3 MC) + 1 O2 raise (7-7.4 MC). Net ~4-4.4 MC/action minus 8 MC energy cost. Building tag (1-2).
Ore Processor.reasoning: One of the better oxygen bumpers. Costs 4 energy per O2 which is better than Iron/Steelworks ratios, and the titanium bonus adds value. icehawk84 ranks it 2nd best bumper after Steelworks. Niche but powerful against plant-production opponents. With colonies, the energy competition makes it less attractive.
Ore Processor.when_to_pick: When you have 4+ energy production and want to deny oxygen to plant players. Not worth setting up specifically for.

Public Celebrations.name: Public Celebrations
Public Celebrations.economy: 11 MC total (8+3) for 2 VP. That is 5.5 MC/VP - fair but not great. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. Chairman requirement manageable in 3P.
Public Celebrations.reasoning: Mediocre VP card with no tags. 5.5 MC/VP is acceptable but not exciting. Chairman requirement is fairly easy to meet at least once per game in 3P. Krazyguy75 calls it 'perfectly mediocre.' Better with IC/Media Group/Vitor discounts. Late game only.
Public Celebrations.when_to_pick: Late game when you have Chairman status. Not worth drafting early. Free draw is fine.

Release of Inert Gases.name: Release of Inert Gases
Release of Inert Gases.economy: 17 MC total (14+3) for 2 TR (~14.8 MC). Slight overpay. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. TR is MC-prod + VP anti-synergy.
Release of Inert Gases.reasoning: Average card that is never great but never terrible. 2 neutral TR for 17 MC is slightly overpriced. No tags is a real penalty. icehawk84 says opponents 'love when their friends play it.' benbever notes TR's income+VP anti-synergy makes it mediocre at any point in the game. Better with event discounts.
Release of Inert Gases.when_to_pick: Late game for VP, or mid-game with event discounts. Never a high priority.

Search For Life.name: Search For Life
Search For Life.economy: 6 MC total (3+3) for cheapest Science tag + stall action + lottery for 3 VP. Max 6% O2 requirement. ~15-20% chance of hitting microbe tag per flip.
Search For Life.reasoning: Cheapest science tag in the game, which is its primary value. The 3 VP lottery is mathematically poor but provides a stall action. Krazyguy75 calls it 'overrated' and notes 6 MC is expensive for a science tag that does nothing else. benbever argues the science tag has real value for unlocking requirements. Max O2 limits playability window.
Search For Life.when_to_pick: Early game when you need a cheap science tag. The action is bonus, not the reason to play it.

Stanford Torus.name: Stanford Torus
Stanford Torus.economy: 12+3=15 MC for 2 VP. Ti-payable (Space tag). With space discounts can go down to 9-11 MC. Base rate: 7.5 MC/VP is poor. City tag for Mayor helps.
Stanford Torus.reasoning: Krazyguy75 correctly notes 15 MC for 2 VP is an awful rate. benbever adds that space discounts and titanium payment help significantly. Best as a late-game ti dump or Mayor push. City+Space tags have some synergies but the card itself is mediocre.
Stanford Torus.when_to_pick: Late game as a titanium dump or if competing for Mayor. With space discounts it becomes more playable.

Tectonic Stress Power.name: Tectonic Stress Power
Tectonic Stress Power.economy: 18+3=21 MC (steel-payable) for 3 energy-prod (22.5 MC) + 1 VP (5 MC) + Power+Building tags. Req 2 Science. Value ~29 MC. Good deal if played early.
Tectonic Stress Power.reasoning: Fair price for 3 energy, but the 2 science tag requirement makes it hard to play gen 1. Without Colonies, energy is less valuable and this is D-tier. With Colonies, 3 energy for trading is excellent and this jumps to B-tier. shai_aus says 'if it were 3-5 MC cheaper I'd like it more.' Format-dependent.
Tectonic Stress Power.when_to_pick: With Colonies and 2+ science tags already. Steel payment makes it more affordable. Skip without Colonies unless you have specific energy needs.

Unexpected Application.name: Unexpected Application
Unexpected Application.economy: 4+3=7 MC + 1 card discard (3-4 MC) = ~10-11 MC effective for 1 Venus TR (9 MC) + Venus tag (~2-3 MC). Roughly break-even. Cheap Venus terraforming.
Unexpected Application.reasoning: No COTD data available. Simple analysis: discard a card + 7 MC for 1 Venus TR is roughly equivalent to standard project asteroid in efficiency but for Venus. The Venus tag helps Venuphile. Cheap event for Legend milestone. Decent but not exciting, and Venus TR is less universally useful than heat/ocean.
Unexpected Application.when_to_pick: When you need to push Venus for requirements or Venuphile. Cheap enough to be fine filler.

Urbanized Area.name: Urbanized Area
Urbanized Area.economy: 10+3=13 MC (steel-payable) - 1 energy-prod (7.5 MC) = ~20.5 MC effective for city tile + 2 MC-prod (10-12 MC). Req: adjacent to 2 cities. Disruptive placement value hard to quantify.
Urbanized Area.reasoning: Niche city card that requires 2 adjacent cities - hard to enable in competitive 3P play where good players avoid enabling it. shai_aus says 'pretty niche' and experienced players avoid creating the setup. ad_hocNC confirms 'good players aren't playing many cities anyway.' Mostly a disruption tool against opponents' city clusters.
Urbanized Area.when_to_pick: When 2 cities are adjacent on the board and you can exploit the placement. Disruption value in 3P. Otherwise skip.

Diversity Support.name: Diversity Support
Diversity Support.economy: 1 TR за 4 MC if condition met.

Venus Waystation.name: Venus Waystation
Venus Waystation.economy: 9+3=12 MC (ti-payable) for -2 MC per Venus tag played + 1 VP (5 MC) + Venus+Space tags (~3-4 MC). Need 4 Venus tags played after this to break even on the discount alone.
Venus Waystation.reasoning: Krazyguy75 highlights the core problem: need 4 Venus tags to break even, and most Venus cards are mediocre. In all-expansions play, Venus tags are diluted. shai_aus agrees. Best for Morning Star Inc who can guarantee Venus plays. The 1 VP and ti-payment help, but the effect is too narrow for most games.
Venus Waystation.when_to_pick: Only when committed to Venus strategy with 3+ Venus cards in hand. Morning Star Inc priority pick.

Adapted Lichen.name: Adapted Lichen
Adapted Lichen.economy: 9+3=12 MC for 1 plant-prod (8 MC gen 1). Plant tag worth 1-2 MC. Net value ~10 MC, cost 12. Slightly overpriced.
Adapted Lichen.reasoning: No-requirement plant production is convenient but expensive at 12 MC for 1 plant-prod. The Plant tag is valuable for NRA, Insects, Ecologist milestone, but standalone the card is weak. Regular Lichen costs 7 MC with an easy requirement. Only worth it gen 1-2 if the tag enables an important combo like NRA.
Adapted Lichen.when_to_pick: Gen 1 only if Plant tag enables NRA or milestone. Otherwise prefer cheaper plant-prod cards like Lichen or Archaebacteria.

Commercial District.name: Commercial District
Commercial District.economy: 16+3=19 MC + 1 energy-prod (7.5 MC) = 26.5 MC. 4 MC-prod (20 MC) + 1-2 VP (5-10 MC) + Building tag (1-2 MC). Steel-payable. Total ~26-33 MC.
Commercial District.reasoning: Too expensive for most situations. 26+ MC effective cost for 4 MC-prod + variable VP is poor early game and the VP is unreliable since experienced players do not cluster cities. The special tile placement is flexible but you are paying a premium for it. As a late-game steel dump with unused energy, it is acceptable. Can swing Banker award. But the card often disappoints -- your VP from adjacency ends up being 1-2 at best.
Commercial District.when_to_pick: Late game steel dump with excess energy, or to swing Banker/Landlord awards. Skip as an economy play.

Extreme-Cold Fungus.name: Extreme-Cold Fungus
Extreme-Cold Fungus.economy: 13 MC + 3 MC card = 16 MC cost. Action: gain 1 plant OR add 2 microbes to any card. Max -10°C requirement. Microbe tag. As plant gen: 16 MC for ~1 plant-prod = terrible. As microbe feeder: depends on target.
Extreme-Cold Fungus.reasoning: Too expensive as a plant generator (16 MC for 1 plant/gen is far worse than Adapted Lichen at 12 MC). The microbe feeding action is the real value, but requires a premium microbe target like GHG Producing Bacteria or Sulphur-Eating Bacteria. Per ad_hocNC, it's 'not worth it most of the time' and 'GHG or bust.' The max -10°C requirement limits it to early game when 16 MC is a huge investment.
Extreme-Cold Fungus.when_to_pick: Only with a high-value microbe target already in play or in hand. Skip for plant generation alone.

Interplanetary Trade.name: Interplanetary Trade
Interplanetary Trade.economy: 27 MC + 3 MC card = 30 MC for N MC-prod (where N = unique tags in play). Need 6+ MC-prod to break even early. Space tag + 1 VP. Ti-payable.
Interplanetary Trade.reasoning: Looks better than it is. At 30 MC cost, you need 6+ different tags for 5 MC/MC-prod ratio, which is barely average. By the time you have 6+ unique tags, it's often mid-late game where production has diminished returns. The 1 VP and Space tag help slightly. Ti-payable is nice but the raw cost is just too high for production.
Interplanetary Trade.when_to_pick: Only as titanium dump when you have 7+ unique tags and 4+ gens remaining. Otherwise pass.

Law Suit.name: Law Suit
Law Suit.economy: 2 MC + 3 MC card = 5 MC. Steal 3 MC from attacker + give them -1 VP. Net: 3 MC gained + 1 VP denied to opponent. Requires being attacked this generation. Earth tag.
Law Suit.reasoning: Conditional and unreliable. In 3P, you may not get attacked, or the attack may come from the player you don't want to help by counter-attacking. The -1 VP to the attacker is nice but the 3 MC steal is minor. In 2P it's significantly better as every attack targets you. The psychological deterrent value (opponents afraid to attack) can be worth more than the card itself.
Law Suit.when_to_pick: In 2P games when you expect to be attacked. In 3P, only as a free draw or if you know you'll be targeted.

Outdoor Sports.name: Outdoor Sports
Outdoor Sports.economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC. Value: 2 MC-prod (10-12) + 1 VP (5). No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Net ~1-3 MC with penalty. Req: city adjacent to ocean.
Outdoor Sports.reasoning: Sponsors-like card but with no tags (huge penalty), 2 MC more expensive, and a clunky requirement. The 1 VP partially compensates but not enough. shai_aus and Krazyguy75 both rate it poorly. benbever notes in all-expansion play the requirement is rarely met gen 1-2 when you'd want it. Sagitta and Community Services slightly help.
Outdoor Sports.when_to_pick: Only when a city is already adjacent to an ocean AND you're gen 1-2. Very low priority in draft.

Red Tourism Wave.name: Red Tourism Wave
Red Tourism Wave.economy: 6 MC total (3+3) for variable MC (1 per empty area adjacent to your tiles). Potential 10-20+ MC with good board position. Requires Reds ruling or 2 delegates. Earth tag.
Red Tourism Wave.reasoning: High ceiling but extremely niche. Reds rarely rule in 3P. Ground game players who benefit most from this card typically do not want Reds in power. Krazyguy75 notes the fundamental design contradiction. Earth tag is nice but the card is too unreliable. When it works it can be 15+ MC but that requires perfect storm of conditions.
Red Tourism Wave.when_to_pick: Only when Reds are already ruling and you have many tiles with empty adjacent spaces. Very situational.

Regolith Eaters.name: Regolith Eaters
Regolith Eaters.economy: 16 MC total (13+3) for Science+Microbe tags (~6-8 MC) + 1 TR per 3 actions (~2.5 MC/gen). Slow oxygen generation.
Regolith Eaters.reasoning: Too expensive and too slow for multiplayer. 3 actions for 1 TR is terrible rate. The Science+Microbe tags provide some value but 16 MC is steep. COTD consensus: mostly for solo, rarely playable in multiplayer. ad_hocNC says 'only play if science tag is very valuable.'
Regolith Eaters.when_to_pick: Only when you desperately need a science tag and have nothing better. The action is almost never worth using.

Sub-zero Salt Fish.name: Sub-zero Salt Fish
Sub-zero Salt Fish.economy: 5+3=8 MC for 1/2 VP per animal + take-that (-1 plant-prod). At -6C, typically 2-3 gens left = 2-3 animals = 1-1.5 VP. With animal placement: slightly better.
Sub-zero Salt Fish.reasoning: SoupsBane notes temperature is usually the lagging parameter, making the -6C requirement very late. icehawk84 confirms it comes online gen 8-9 in competitive play. 1/2 VP per animal is worse than Birds/Fish. Take-that element is minor. Cheap but arrives too late to accumulate meaningful VP.
Sub-zero Salt Fish.when_to_pick: Late game filler if temperature is somehow ahead. Much worse than Fish/Small Animals in practice.

Tundra Farming.name: Tundra Farming
Tundra Farming.economy: 16+3=19 MC for 1 plant-prod (8 MC) + 2 MC-prod (10-12 MC) + 1 plant (2 MC) + 2 VP (10 MC) + Plant tag. Req -6C. Total ~32 MC value but comes very late.
Tundra Farming.reasoning: ad_hocNC calls it 'one of the worst plant cards.' At -6C, only 1-2 gens of plant-prod left, meaning ~1 extra greenery at best. shai_aus prefers Trees (cheaper, more plant-prod, similar requirement). 2 VP for 19 MC is passable but the timing makes everything else low value. Worse than Trees, Farming, Bushes.
Tundra Farming.when_to_pick: Only if -6C is met and you need the plant tag or the 2 VP. Trees is almost always better if you can wait for -4C.

Asteroid Mining.name: Asteroid Mining
Asteroid Mining.economy: 30+3=33 MC for 2 ti-prod (25 MC) + 2 VP (10 MC) + Jovian tag (3-5 MC) + Space tag (1-2 MC). Total ~39-42 MC. Ti-payable. Break-even ~gen 4 if played gen 1.
Asteroid Mining.reasoning: Very expensive at 33 MC for production that takes ~5.5 gens to return the investment. The Jovian + Space tags add value for multipliers but the core economics are poor. In 3P/WGT games ending gen 8-9, playing this gen 1 barely breaks even. With Phobolog (ti worth 4 each) the math improves significantly. Without heavy ti synergy, this is too slow and expensive.
Asteroid Mining.when_to_pick: Phobolog gen 1 or Saturn Systems with ti preludes. Jovian strategy with multipliers. Otherwise skip.

Carbonate Processing.name: Carbonate Processing
Carbonate Processing.economy: 6+3=9 MC + 1 energy-prod (7.5 MC) = 16.5 MC effective. 3 heat-prod (12 MC) + Building tag (1-2 MC). Net ~13 MC for 16.5 MC cost. Overpays.
Carbonate Processing.reasoning: Converting energy to heat production is a downgrade in most games (energy > heat). 3 heat-prod needs ~24 heat = 3 temperature raises = 3 TR over ~8 gens, but that is slow and the heat-to-TR conversion is inherently overpriced. The Building tag is minor. Only worth it for dedicated heat rushers with excess energy. In 3P/WGT, heat strategies are generally weaker.
Carbonate Processing.when_to_pick: Gen 1 only, for dedicated heat rush with excess energy-prod. Otherwise skip.

Cloud Seeding.name: Cloud Seeding
Cloud Seeding.economy: 11+3=14 MC + 1 MC-prod (5 MC) for 2 plant-prod (16 MC). Net: 14+5=19 MC cost, 16 MC value. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. Take-that: -1 heat-prod in 3P = helps 3rd player.
Cloud Seeding.reasoning: 2 plant-prod for effectively 19 MC is overpriced. The -1 MC-prod and -1 opponent heat-prod downsides are significant. No tags means zero synergy value. The take-that aspect (reducing opponent heat-prod) helps the third player in 3P. The 3 ocean requirement is mild but adds timing constraints. If it had a Plant tag it would be better. As is, a below-average plant production card.
Cloud Seeding.when_to_pick: Only when you have no better plant-prod options and 3 oceans are out. Low priority.

Energy Saving.name: Energy Saving
Energy Saving.economy: 15 MC + 3 MC card = 18 MC cost. Returns: X energy-prod where X = cities in play. In 3P mid-game typically 2-3 cities = 15-22.5 MC. Late game 4-5 cities = 30-37.5 MC but energy less useful.
Energy Saving.reasoning: Too dependent on other players building cities, which in 3P with all expansions happens slowly. Per shai_aus, most decent opponents don't go nuts for city building early. In 3P, you might see 2-3 cities by mid-game at best, making this 18 MC for 2-3 energy production — barely break even. Only shines with Physics Complex combo or in city-heavy metagames. The Power tag is almost irrelevant.
Energy Saving.when_to_pick: Mid-late game with 4+ cities already in play and a use for energy (colonies, Physics Complex). Otherwise skip.

GHG Shipment.name: GHG Shipment
GHG Shipment.economy: 3 MC + 3 MC card = 6 MC cost. Returns: 1 heat-prod (~4 MC gen1) + X heat (X = floaters you have). Requires Kelvinists ruling. Event tag.
GHG Shipment.reasoning: Highly conditional card with low payoff. Kelvinists ruling requirement adds major friction. 1 heat production for 6 MC is bad value (4 MC return gen1). The floater-to-heat conversion is only good if you have 10+ floaters stored, which is extremely rare. Even then, heat resources are among the least valuable. No meaningful tags beyond event. Almost always skip.
GHG Shipment.when_to_pick: Only if Kelvinists are ruling, you have 10+ floaters, and need heat. Extremely niche.

Immigration Shuttles.name: Immigration Shuttles
Immigration Shuttles.economy: 31 MC + 3 MC card = 34 MC for 5 MC-prod (~25 MC gen 1) + 1/3 VP per city (~2-3 VP typical). Earth+Space tags (~4 MC). With titanium: much better. Without: overpriced.
Immigration Shuttles.reasoning: Too expensive for what it provides. At 34 MC, the 5 MC-prod only pays back in ~7 gens which is the whole game. The VP from cities is unreliable since competitive players don't spam cities. Earth+Space tags and ti-payable are the saving graces. Only worthwhile as a titanium dump or with Phobolog. Consistently rated D-tier by experienced players.
Immigration Shuttles.when_to_pick: When swimming in titanium with no other space cards to play. Decent Phobolog titanium dump.

Ishtar Mining.name: Ishtar Mining
Ishtar Mining.economy: 5 MC + 3 MC card = 8 MC for 1 ti-prod (~12.5 MC). Requires Venus 8%. Good value IF playable early, but Venus 8% is often mid-game or later. Venus tag. No Building tag, can't pay in steel.
Ishtar Mining.reasoning: Looks efficient at 8 MC for 12.5 MC ti-prod value, but the Venus 8% requirement typically delays this to mid-game when production has diminishing returns. Compare to Titanium Mine (7 MC, no req, Building tag, steel payable). The Venus tag has some synergy value but the requirement-to-payoff ratio is poor. Only worth it with Morning Star Inc or early Venus terraforming.
Ishtar Mining.when_to_pick: Only when Venus 8% is already met or about to be met, and you need cheap Venus tag + ti-prod. Otherwise Titanium Mine is better.

Lava Tube Settlement.name: Lava Tube Settlement
Lava Tube Settlement.economy: 15 MC + 3 MC card + 7.5 MC (1 energy prod) = ~25.5 MC for city + 2 MC-prod (~10 MC). Only 2 MC-prod vs typical 3 for cities. Volcanic area restriction severely limits placement.
Lava Tube Settlement.reasoning: Overpriced city with terrible placement restrictions. Only 4 legal spots on Tharsis/Elysium, none particularly good for city adjacency VP. The 2 MC-prod vs typical 3 is a significant downgrade. Energy cost is painful. Barely cheaper than SP City (25 MC, no energy cost, free placement). Building+City tags are the only positives. Better on Hellas where volcanic areas have decent bonuses.
Lava Tube Settlement.when_to_pick: Only on Hellas with leftover energy and steel, or for a critical Mayor milestone push.

Microgravity Nutrition.name: Microgravity Nutrition
Microgravity Nutrition.economy: Cost 11+3=14 MC. Value: 1 VP (5) + Microbe+Plant tags (3-4) + 1 MC-prod per colony. At 2 colonies = 10 MC-prod; at 3 = 15. Total ~18-24 with 2-3 colonies.
Microgravity Nutrition.reasoning: Requires multiple colonies early to be worthwhile, which is uncommon in 3P. The Microbe+Plant double bio-tag is decent for milestones but the effect is weak. FieldMouse007 calls it mediocre. At 2 colonies it's barely break-even considering gen played. Niche card that rarely excites.
Microgravity Nutrition.when_to_pick: Only with 3+ colonies already placed early game. The double bio-tag is the main appeal for specific milestones.

Public Plans.name: Public Plans
Public Plans.economy: 10 MC total (7+3) for 1 VP + ~X MC refund (1 MC per revealed card). No tags = big penalty. Revealing hand gives opponents information.
Public Plans.reasoning: No tags, gives opponents information, and the MC refund is small. 10 MC for 1 VP + a few MC back is poor efficiency. The information leak is a real downside in competitive play. No COTD data confirms it is underplayed. Niche at best.
Public Plans.when_to_pick: Almost never. Only if you have many cards in hand, strong discounts, and need Legend milestone.

Special Design.name: Special Design
Special Design.economy: 7 MC total (4+3) for +/- 2 steps on next card's requirement + Science event tag. Effectively 7 MC to play a card 1 gen earlier, which is rarely worth 7 MC.
Special Design.reasoning: The effect is too small and too expensive. +/- 2 steps is only 1 generation difference in most cases. Krazyguy75 rates it 'extremely hard to justify' and 'awful.' benbever argues it is underrated for unlocking Kelp Farming/Trees early, but even then the 7 MC cost is steep. Science tag has some value. Mostly played as a cheap science event for triggers.
synergies: Science event triggers (Mars U, IC, Media Group)
Special Design.when_to_pick: Only when the extra 2 steps unlocks a very powerful card 1 gen earlier. Very niche.

Venusian Insects.name: Venusian Insects
Venusian Insects.economy: 5+3=8 MC for action: add 1 microbe, 1 VP per 2 microbes. Req Venus 12%. Venus+Microbe tags ~3 MC. In 3 gens: 3 microbes = 1.5 VP = ~7.5 MC. Req limits timing.
Venusian Insects.reasoning: Similar to Tardigrades but with Venus requirement and slightly better VP rate (1/2 vs 1/4). The Venus 12% requirement delays deployment in all-expansions play. 1 VP per 2 microbes is still subpar for animal placement. Venus+Microbe tags have some value for Ecologist. Strictly worse than 1/resource animals.
Venusian Insects.when_to_pick: When Venus 12% is met and you need VP accumulation. Significantly worse than Stratospheric Birds or Venusian Animals.

Venusian Plants.name: Venusian Plants
Venusian Plants.economy: 13+3=16 MC for 1 Venus TR (9 MC) + 1 VP (5 MC) + 1 microbe/animal on Venus card (~2-5 MC) + Venus+Plant tags (~3-4 MC). Req Venus 16%. Total ~19-23 MC value if fully used.
Venusian Plants.reasoning: Venus 16% (8 steps) is extremely hard to achieve in all-expansions play. shai_aus says '13+3 MC for hopefully 3 points is not amazing.' The microbe/animal placement is limited to Venus cards, restricting value. ThainEshKelch notes 'chances are it won't get played at all.' When playable it's decent, but the requirement kills it.
Venusian Plants.when_to_pick: Only when Venus is at 16%+ and you have a Venus animal card to place on. Very rare in practice.

Adaptation Technology.name: Adaptation Technology
Adaptation Technology.economy: 12+3=15 MC for 1 VP (5 MC) + Science tag (3-5 MC) + effect. Net value from card itself ~8-10 MC. Effect is situational and rarely worth the 5-7 MC gap.
Adaptation Technology.reasoning: As COTD commenters unanimously note, the effect is too expensive and too situational for the price. The +/-2 requirement steps rarely matters enough to justify 15 MC. You might play 1-2 cards a generation earlier, but that is usually not worth the investment. The Science tag and VP partially compensate but not enough. Inventrix already gives this effect for free.
Adaptation Technology.when_to_pick: Only when you desperately need a Science tag and the effect will let you play 2+ requirement cards earlier. Almost always a pass.

Atmo Collectors.name: Atmo Collectors
Atmo Collectors.economy: 15+3=18 MC for no tags + 2 floaters. Action: spend 1 floater for 2 energy or 3 heat or 1 MC-prod. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty.
Atmo Collectors.reasoning: The no-tag penalty hurts significantly. 18 MC for a slow action card that converts floaters to small amounts of resources is poor value. The action choices are flexible but individually weak. You need external floater sources to sustain the action beyond 2 uses. Without tags, you lose all corporate and milestone synergies. Mostly a trap card unless you desperately need specific resources.
Atmo Collectors.when_to_pick: Almost never. Only if you have abundant floater generation and desperately need energy/heat conversion.

Extractor Balloons.name: Extractor Balloons
Extractor Balloons.economy: 21 MC + 3 MC card = 24 MC cost. Starts with 3 floaters. Action: add 1 floater or spend 3 for Venus raise. Gen 1 play: 1 TR immediate, 1 TR gen 3, 1 TR gen 6. ~3 TR for 24 MC over 6 gens.
Extractor Balloons.reasoning: Overpriced Venus terraformer. At 24 MC, getting 3 TR over 6 generations is too slow — the income from early TR is minimal and games often end before gen 6. Per shai_aus, it's like GHG bacteria but way more expensive and raises Venus instead of temperature. Per benbever's math, it's actually better than most microbe cards due to the 3 starting floaters, but the 24 MC cost is brutal for gen 1 economy. Only good with Celestic/Stormcraft for Hoverlord snipe.
Extractor Balloons.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 with Celestic/Stormcraft for Hoverlord claim. Otherwise too slow and expensive.

Great Escarpment Consortium.name: Great Escarpment Consortium
Great Escarpment Consortium.economy: 6 MC + 3 MC card = 9 MC cost. Returns: net +1 steel-prod (~8 MC gen1) by taking from another player. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. Take-that card.
Great Escarpment Consortium.reasoning: Classic take-that trap in 3P. You gain 1 steel production while one opponent loses 1 — the third player benefits for free. Per the 3P take-that penalty pattern, this is -5 to -10 score. At 9 MC for 1 steel-prod (~8 MC) with no tags, you're paying slightly above value AND hurting one opponent which helps the third player. The 'requires steel production' clause means you need a target. Avoid in 3P.
Great Escarpment Consortium.when_to_pick: Rarely in 3P. Only if you desperately need steel production AND one specific opponent has excess. Better in 2P.

Hospitals.name: Hospitals
Hospitals.economy: 8 MC + 3 MC card + 7.5 MC (1 energy prod) = ~18.5 MC cost. 1 VP. Gains 3 MC per city placed (but must have fewer disease resources than threshold). Unreliable income stream.
Hospitals.reasoning: Confusing and unreliable card. Requires energy production, generates disease resources based on cities which need to be managed through an action, and the MC generation is inconsistent. In 3P games cities aren't placed frequently enough. Essentially a worse version of Martian Rails. The 1 VP and Building tag for steel payment are the only positives.
Hospitals.when_to_pick: Rarely. Last-gen cheap VP point with steel if you have nothing better. Skip in most situations.

Neutralizer Factory.name: Neutralizer Factory
Neutralizer Factory.economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: 1 Venus TR (7-7.4) + Venus tag (2-3). Total ~9-10 MC. Net ~-1 to 0 MC. Req: 10% Venus.
Neutralizer Factory.reasoning: 10 MC for 1 TR is mediocre, and the 10% Venus requirement means you can't play it until mid-game. The Venus tag has some value for Venuphile award. benbever notes it rarely sees play. Most COTD comments are dismissive. It's not terrible but there's almost always something better to spend MC on.
Neutralizer Factory.when_to_pick: Only when Venus is near 14-16% and you want the bonus TR from reaching the threshold. Very low priority.

Snow Algae.name: Snow Algae
Snow Algae.economy: 15 MC total (12+3) for 1 plant prod (~8 MC) + 1 heat prod (~4-6 MC) + Plant tag (~1-2 MC). Req: 2 oceans. Total value ~13-16 MC. Slightly overpriced.
Snow Algae.reasoning: Overpriced combination of two mediocre productions. shai_aus says 'hard pass, too pricey.' The 2 ocean requirement prevents gen 1 play when production matters most. 1 plant prod + 1 heat prod alone do little. Plant tag is nice but not enough to save the card. icehawk84 confirms the main problem is standalone productions do not do much.
Snow Algae.when_to_pick: Only gen 1-2 with 2 oceans already placed and a plant/heat strategy. Otherwise skip.

Solar Power.name: Solar Power
Solar Power.economy: 14 MC total (11+3) for 1 energy prod (~7.5 MC) + 1 VP (~5 MC) + Power+Building tags (~2 MC). Total ~14.5 MC. Break-even at best.
Solar Power.reasoning: Overpriced for what it does. shai_aus says 'too expensive for energy early, too expensive for VP late.' The VP+energy production anti-synergy is the core problem. Only truly playable as a steel dump or when you desperately need energy with a building tag. Worse than Power Plant in almost every way except it has 1 VP.
Solar Power.when_to_pick: Late game steel dump for 1 VP. Not worth drafting unless desperate for building/power tags.

Tardigrades.name: Tardigrades
Tardigrades.economy: 4+3=7 MC for action: add 1 microbe, 1 VP per 4 microbes. Gen 1 play in 8-gen game: 8 microbes = 2 VP = ~10 MC. Net +3 MC. Microbe tag worth ~1-2 MC.
Tardigrades.reasoning: Krazyguy75 nails it: the biggest downside is opportunity cost of drawing a better card. 2 VP for 7 MC is acceptable, but only with 8+ gens of accumulation. 1/4 VP rate is terrible for animal placement. Vulnerable to Ants. Low impact, low synergy. Fine as filler but not worth prioritizing.
Tardigrades.when_to_pick: Gen 1 filler when you have nothing better. Cheap tag for Ecologist/Diversifier. Never a priority pick.

Vote Of No Confidence.name: Vote Of No Confidence
Vote Of No Confidence.economy: 5+3=8 MC for 1 TR (7 MC) + chairman position (1 influence, ~2-4 MC/gen in Turmoil events). Net: slightly positive if requirements met. No tags is a penalty (-3 to -5).
Vote Of No Confidence.reasoning: Krazyguy75 correctly identifies the problem: 'neutral chairman + you have a party leader' is out of your control and rarely happens when you need it. The card rots in hand for most of the game. No tags means no synergy value. When it fires, 1 TR + chairman is good for 8 MC. But holding cost and unpredictability make it unreliable.
Vote Of No Confidence.when_to_pick: Don't hold this early. Maybe draft if it's late game and neutral chairman is about to happen. Otherwise skip.

Water Splitting Plant.name: Water Splitting Plant
Water Splitting Plant.economy: 12+3=15 MC for action: spend 3 energy for 1 O2 TR (7 MC). Energy valued at ~3x7.5=22.5 MC prod. Very expensive per TR. Building tag ~1-2 MC. Req 2 oceans.
Water Splitting Plant.reasoning: Like other O2 bumpers, generally bad in multiplayer because greeneries handle O2 while providing VP. 3 energy per TR is expensive (equivalent to ~22 MC production for an action that gives 7 MC). Only useful with Mass Converter or excess energy in late game. The 2 ocean requirement is usually easy to meet.
Water Splitting Plant.when_to_pick: Only with excess energy production and O2 not yet maxed. Rarely correct in competitive 3P play.

Hackers.name: Hackers
Hackers.reasoning: В 2P сильная, в 3P = D-тир. Третий игрок выигрывает бесплатно.

Callisto Penal Mines.name: Callisto Penal Mines
Callisto Penal Mines.economy: 24+3=27 MC for 3 MC-prod (15 MC) + 2 VP (10 MC) + Jovian tag (3-5 MC) + Space tag (1-2 MC). Total ~29-32 MC. Ti-payable. Break-even after ~8+ gens.
Callisto Penal Mines.reasoning: As COTD unanimously agrees, way too expensive for what it does. MC-prod and VP have anti-synergy (one is early-game, other is late-game). 27 MC for 3 MC-prod in gen 1 barely returns the investment by game end. The Jovian + Space tags add some value for multiplier strategies, but there are cheaper Jovian tags. Only playable as a ti dump with Phobolog or with Jovian multipliers. Classic Jovian trap.
Callisto Penal Mines.when_to_pick: Only when playing Jovian strategy with multipliers or as a late-game ti dump for the Jovian tag.

Capital.name: Capital
Capital.economy: 26+3=29 MC + 2 energy-prod (15 MC) = 44 MC effective. 5 MC-prod (25 MC) + special VP (1/ocean adj, typically 2-4 VP = 10-20 MC). Steel-payable. 4 ocean req.
Capital.reasoning: The most expensive city in the game. Even counting ocean adjacency VP (typically 2-3 VP), the economics are poor. 44 MC effective cost for 5 MC-prod that takes 9+ gens to return. The 4 ocean requirement limits when you can play it. The VP from ocean adjacency is variable and often disappointing. Only worth it as a very late-game steel dump with excess energy. Most experienced players consider it a trap.
Capital.when_to_pick: Late game only, with excess steel and energy production. Good placement spots are rare.

Forced Precipitation.name: Forced Precipitation
Forced Precipitation.economy: 8 MC + 3 MC card = 11 MC cost. Action: 2 MC → 1 floater, or spend 2 floaters for Venus raise. Effective: 15 MC for first Venus TR in gen 3. 19 MC for second in gen 6. Very slow.
Forced Precipitation.reasoning: Bad Venus terraformer. Per Krazyguy75, the math shows 12 MC effort for 8-9 MC in Venus value — poor ROI. Per benbever's detailed analysis, it's worse than Giant Solar Shade, Extractor Balloons, and even Thermophiles despite having no requirement. The 3-gen delay for first TR is crippling. Only the Venus tag and floater target capability provide some value. Per Futuralis, it's almost never played.
Forced Precipitation.when_to_pick: Only as a cheap Venus tag or when you have external floater sources. Very low priority for actual Venus terraforming.

Sabotage.name: Sabotage
Sabotage.economy: 4 MC total (1+3) to remove 7 MC / 4 steel / 3 titanium from opponent. No tags. Take-that in 3P = -5 to -10. Pure attack with no self-benefit.
Sabotage.reasoning: Classic take-that trap in 3P. You spend 4 MC to hurt one opponent, benefiting the third player for free. No tags, no self-benefit. Krazyguy75 dislikes the entire category. Only playable for free with IC/Media Group or to deny a specific milestone. benbever notes it is played more in 2P.
Sabotage.when_to_pick: Almost never in 3P. Only with event rebates/discounts or to deny a critical milestone.

Colonial Envoys.name: Colonial Envoys
Colonial Envoys.economy: 4+3=7 MC for delegates (value depends on colonies owned, ~3-5 MC per delegate). Requires Unity ruling + colonies + turmoil. No tags. Very restrictive.
Colonial Envoys.reasoning: Triple restriction: needs Unity ruling, colonies expansion, and turmoil expansion, plus you need multiple colonies built. No tags. Even when playable, placing 2-3 delegates is a minor effect worth maybe 6-15 MC. The conditions align too rarely to be reliable. No COTD expert data (only 1 non-key comment). Too narrow for consistent value.
Colonial Envoys.when_to_pick: Only with 3+ colonies and Unity is ruling or about to rule. Very low priority.

Equatorial Magnetizer.name: Equatorial Magnetizer
Equatorial Magnetizer.economy: 11 MC (steel payable) + 3 MC card = 14 MC cost. Action: -1 energy-prod → +1 TR (~7.2 MC value). Net: ~0.2 MC profit per use minus the 14 MC upfront cost. Need 2+ uses to break even.
Equatorial Magnetizer.reasoning: Bad card. Per Krazyguy75, even unused energy is worth ~6 MC as heat, so paying 14 MC upfront for an action that generates ~1 MC profit is terrible. Per ad_hocNC, people mistake the action cost for the total cost. Per benbever, sometimes playable late game with excess energy production, but at 14 MC for 1-2 points, it's rarely worthwhile. Building tag for steel payment is the only redeeming quality.
Equatorial Magnetizer.when_to_pick: Late game with 3+ excess energy production and steel to pay for it. Very low priority otherwise.

Heat Trappers.name: Heat Trappers
Heat Trappers.economy: 6 MC + 3 MC card + 1 VP penalty = ~14 MC effective cost. Gain 7.5 MC (1 energy prod). Destroy ~8 MC (2 heat prod) from opponent. Net: you spend 14 MC, gain 7.5, destroy 8 from one opponent.
Heat Trappers.reasoning: Classic take-that card that helps the third player in 3P. You pay 14 MC effectively, gain only 7.5 MC, and hurt one opponent while the third player benefits free. -1 VP makes it worse. Much better in 2P but in our 3P format this is a losing play. Building tag and Robotic Workforce combo is the only saving grace.
Heat Trappers.when_to_pick: Only in 2P or if one opponent is running away with the game via heat production and you must slow them specifically.

Magnetic Field Dome.name: Magnetic Field Dome
Magnetic Field Dome.economy: 5 MC + 3 MC card + 15 MC (2 energy prod) = ~23 MC for 1 TR (~7 MC) + 1 plant prod (~8 MC) + Building tag (~2 MC) = ~17 MC value. 6 MC deficit.
Magnetic Field Dome.reasoning: Overcosted for what it provides. The 2 energy production cost is steep, and the return of 1 TR + 1 plant prod doesn't justify it in most situations. Only useful as a last-gen TR point with excess energy, or when the plant production enables an extra greenery in the final greenery phase. Building tag for steel payment is minor consolation.
Magnetic Field Dome.when_to_pick: Last gen with 2+ unused energy production and steel to dump. Otherwise skip. Never play early/mid game.

Meltworks.name: Meltworks
Meltworks.economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC (steel payable). Action: 5 heat (6 MC) -> 3 steel (6 MC). Net 0 per action. Building tag (1-2). Need heat surplus with steel targets.
Meltworks.reasoning: Very niche heat-to-steel converter that barely breaks even on the action. The 7 MC upfront cost means you need several uses just to recover investment. Only worthwhile with Advanced Alloys/Rego Plastics (3 steel = 9-12 MC). shai_aus and most COTD experts find it too situational. Building tag is the main appeal.
Meltworks.when_to_pick: Only with Advanced Alloys AND heat surplus AND steel targets. Or as a cheap building tag for Builder milestone.

Rad-Suits.name: Rad-Suits
Rad-Suits.economy: 9 MC total (6+3) for 1 MC-prod + 1 VP. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty. Effective cost ~4.5 MC for MC-prod and ~4.5 MC for VP. Both are overpriced.
Rad-Suits.reasoning: Awful card per Krazyguy75's analysis. No tags, low impact, essentially a worse TR for 9 MC. The 2 cities requirement is trivial but the card just does not do enough. shai_aus says 'fine for a point' but not impactful. Community Services synergy exists but is niche.
Rad-Suits.when_to_pick: Only as a last-gen VP dump when you have nothing better. Never draft early.

Sulphur Exports.name: Sulphur Exports
Sulphur Exports.economy: 21+3=24 MC (ti-payable) for 1 Venus TR (9 MC) + 1 MC-prod per Venus tag. With 3 Venus tags total: 9+15=24 MC value = break even. Need 4+ tags to profit.
Sulphur Exports.reasoning: Too expensive for what it does. shai_aus compares it unfavorably to Satellites. Community consensus is D-tier unless you somehow have 4+ Venus tags, which is rare in all-expansions play. Venus tags are scarce and often not worth prioritizing for this payoff.
Sulphur Exports.when_to_pick: Only with 4+ Venus tags already in play/hand. MSI is the most common enabler. Otherwise skip.

Black Polar Dust.name: Black Polar Dust
Black Polar Dust.economy: 15+3=18 MC for 1 ocean (14 MC) + 3 heat-prod (12 MC) - 2 MC-prod (-10 MC). Net value ~16 MC. No tags = -3 to -5 penalty.
Black Polar Dust.reasoning: Same cost as SP ocean but you lose 2 MC-prod and gain 3 heat-prod. The net production swap is roughly -1 MC-prod after TR from ocean. The no-tag penalty is significant -- zero synergy value. Heat production is less valuable than MC production in most games. Only playable for rushers who want heat for temperature and need an ocean. As COTD notes, it is underwhelming and rarely exciting.
Black Polar Dust.when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 for rush strategy when you need both ocean and heat production. Skip if you value MC-prod or tags.

Teslaract.name: Teslaract
Teslaract.economy: 14+3=17 MC (steel-payable) for 1 TR (7 MC) + action: spend 1 energy-prod to gain 1 plant-prod. Power+Building tags. Plant-prod ~8 MC vs energy-prod ~7.5 MC: marginal gain per activation.
Teslaract.reasoning: icehawk84 compares to Soil Factory and gives D tier. The energy-to-plant conversion is marginal value (plant prod only slightly better than energy prod). 17 MC upfront for 1 TR and a weak action is poor. FieldMouse007 says 'situational, rarely great.' Only works with cheap excess energy production.
Teslaract.when_to_pick: Only with excess cheap energy production and a plant-based strategy. Very niche.

Venus Soils.name: Venus Soils
Venus Soils.economy: 20+3=23 MC for 1 Venus TR (9 MC) + 1 plant-prod (8 MC) + 2 microbes (~2-5 MC) + Venus+Plant tags (~3-4 MC). Total ~22-26 MC. Break-even but can't pay with steel/ti.
Venus Soils.reasoning: shai_aus asks 'Why is it so expensive?' ad_hocNC agrees it's overpriced. The card gives a package of things you rarely all need together. Venus TR + plant-prod + microbes is a weird combo that doesn't suit most strategies. No steel/ti payment makes the 23 MC cash cost painful. Only worthwhile with NRA/Insects + microbe target + Venus need.
Venus Soils.when_to_pick: Only when you need all three: Venus step, plant-prod, and microbe target. Very niche package deal.

Banned Delegate.name: Banned Delegate
Banned Delegate.economy: 0+3=3 MC for removing 1 delegate. Value: 0-5 MC depending on timing (can secure chairman = 1 TR, or swing a party ruling). No tags. Chairman requirement is harsh.
Banned Delegate.reasoning: Very narrow card. The Chairman requirement means you can only play this when you are already Chairman, which is not frequent. Even when playable, removing 1 delegate is a minor effect. The no-tag penalty and event type with no tags give no synergy value. Can occasionally be valuable for securing a second term as Chairman or swinging a crucial party vote, but these moments are rare in 3P.
Banned Delegate.when_to_pick: Very low priority. Only if you are frequently Chairman and need to manipulate party politics.

Designed Microorganisms.name: Designed Microorganisms
Designed Microorganisms.economy: 16 MC + 3 MC card = 19 MC cost. Returns: 2 plant-prod (~16 MC gen1) + Science+Microbe tags (~5 MC). Total ~21 MC. Looks balanced, but plant-prod early is weak.
Designed Microorganisms.reasoning: Way too expensive for 2 plant production. The max -14°C requirement means it must be played early when 19 MC for plant production is a terrible investment — you want engine/economy cards, not slow greenery conversion. Per shai_aus (consistent across 3 COTD posts), this card is just too expensive. The Science tag is nice but not worth the price. Would need to be 3-4 MC cheaper to be playable.
Designed Microorganisms.when_to_pick: Almost never. Only if desperate for a Science tag with Ecoline going for early Gardener milestone.

Icy Impactors.name: Icy Impactors
Icy Impactors.economy: 15 MC + 3 MC card = 18 MC upfront. Then 10 MC per 2 asteroids = 1 ocean per 2 actions. First ocean: 18+10 = 28 MC + 2 actions. Subsequent: 10 MC + 2 actions each. Slow and you don't choose placement.
